question: Couple a weeks. Don't do nothin' you wouldn't want me to hear about!
answer: How about a lift, mister?

question: Can't you see that sticker?
answer: Sure I see it. But a good guy don't pay no attention to what some heel makes him stick on his truck.

question: Scrunch down on the running board till we get around the bend. Goin' far?
answer: Just a few miles. I'd a walked her if my dogs wasn't pooped out.

question: Lookin' for a job?
answer: No, my old man got a place, forty acres. He's a sharecropper, but we been there a long time.

question: Oh! Been doin' a job?
answer: Yeah.

question: I seen your hands. You been swinging a pick or a sledge--that shines up your hands. I notice little things like that all the time. Got a trade?
answer: Why don't you get to it, buddy?

question: Get to what?
answer: You know what I mean. You been givin' me a goin' over ever since I got in. Whyn't you go on and ask me where I been?

question: I don't stick my nose in nobody's business.
answer: Naw--not much!

question: I stay in my own yard.
answer: Listen. That big nose of yours been goin' over me like a sheep in a vegetable patch. But I ain't keepin' it a secret. I been in the penitentiary. Been there four years. Like to know anything else?

question: You ain't got to get sore.
answer: Go ahead. Ask me anything you want.

question: I didn't mean nothing.
answer: Me neither. I'm just tryin' to get along without shovin' anybody around, that's all. See that road up ahead?

question: Yeah.
answer: That's where I get off. You're about to bust to know what I done, ain't you? Well, I ain't a guy to let you down. Homicide!

question: I never asked you!
answer: Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.

question: Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.
answer: Mmmmm he's my saviour. Mmmmm my saviour, Mmmmmmmmmm my saviour now. Howdy, friend.

question: Howdy.
answer: Say, ain't you young Tom Joad--ol' Tom's boy?

question: Yeah. On my way home now.
answer: Well, I do declare! I baptized you, son.

question: Why, you're the preacher!
answer: *Used* to be. Not no more. I lost the call. But boy, I sure *used* to have it! I'd get an irrigation ditch so squirmin' full of repented sinners I pretty near *drowned* half of 'em! But not no more. I lost the sperit.

question: Pa always said you was never cut out to be a preacher.
answer: I got nothin' to preach about no more--that's all. I ain't so sure o' things.

question: Maybe you should a got yourself a wife.
answer: At my meetin's I used to get the girls glory-shoutin' till they about passed out. Then, I'd go to comfort 'em--and always end up by lovin' 'em. I'd feel bad, an' pray, an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Next time, do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me.

question: I never let one go by me when I could catch her.
answer: But you wasn't a preacher. A girl was just a girl to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls. I ast myself--what *is* this call, the Holy Sperit? Maybe *that's* love. Why, I love everybody so much I'm fit to bust sometimes! So maybe there ain't no sin an' there ain't no virtue. There's just what people do. Some things folks do is nice, and some ain't so nice. But that's as far as any man's got a right to say.

question: Have a little snort?
answer: Course I'll say grace if somebody sets out the food-- --but my heart ain't in it. Nice drinkin' liquor.

question: Ought to be. That's fact'ry liquor. Cost me a buck.
answer: Been out travelin' around?

question: Didn't you hear? It was in the papers.
answer: No, I never. What?

question: I been in the penitentiary for four years.
answer: Excuse me for asking.

question: I don't mind any more. I'd do what I done again. I killed a guy at a dance. We was drunk. He got a knife in me and I laid him out with a shovel. Knocked his head plumb to squash.
answer: And you ain't ashamed?

question: He had a knife in me. That's why they only gave me seven years. Got out in four--parole.
answer: Ain't you seen your folks since then?

question: No, but I aim to before sundown. Gettin' kind of excited about it, too. Which way you going?
answer: It don't matter. Ever since I lost the sperit it looks like I just as soon go one way as the other. I'll go your way.

question: Maybe Ma'll have pork for supper. I ain't had pork but four times in four years--every Christmas.
answer: I'll be glad to see you pa. Last time I seen him was at a baptizin', an' he had one a the bigges' doses of the Holy Sperit I ever seen. He go to jumpin' over bushes, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon-time. Fin'ly he picks hisself out a bush big as a piana an' he let out a squawk an' took a run at that bush. Well, sir, he cleared her but he bust his leg snap in two. They was a travellin' dentist there and he set her, an' I give her a prayin' over, but they wasn't no more Holy Sperit in your pa after that.

question: Lissen. This wind's fixin't to *do* somepin'!
answer: Shore it is. It always is, this time a year. Is it fur?

question: Just around that next bend.
answer: Your granma was a great one, too. The third time she got religion she go it so powerful she knocked down a full-growed deacon with her fist.

question: That's our place.
answer: And it ain't any too close, either! We better run!

question: They're all gone--or dead.
answer: They never wrote you nothing?

question: No. They wasn't people to write. This was Ma's. Had 'em for years. This used to be mine. I give it to Grampa when I went away. You reckon they could be dead?
answer: I never heard nothin' about it.

question: All right, you remember the *man* then. Now where is my folks?
answer: Gone-- --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got *his* notice to get off.

question: But what's happened? How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.
answer: Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks. Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.

question: But who done it?
answer: Listen! That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.

question: Are you crazy?
answer: Some say I am. You want to hear what happened?

question: That's what I asked you, ain't it?
answer: The way it happens--the way it happened to me--the man come one day...

question: The way it happens--the way it happened to me--the man come one day...
answer: Fact of the matter, Muley, after what them dusters done to the land, the tenant system don't work no more. It don't even break even, much less show a profit. One man on a tractor can handle twelve or fourteen of these places. You just pay him a wage and take *all* the crop.

question: But we couldn't *do* on any less'n what our share is now. The chillun ain't gettin' enough to eat as it is, and they're so ragged we'd be shamed if ever'body else's chillun wasn't the same way.
answer: I can't help that. All I know is I got my orders. They told me to tell you you got to get off, and that's what I'm telling you.

question: You mean get off my own land?
answer: Now don't go blaming me. It ain't *my* fault. You know who owns the land--the Shawnee Land and Cattle Company.

question: Who's the Shawnee Land and Cattle Comp'ny?
answer: It ain't nobody. It's a company. But it ain't *his* fault, because the *bank* tells him what to do. Tulsa. But what's the use of picking on him? He ain't anything but the manager, and half crazy hisself, trying to keep up with his orders from the east!

question: Then who *do* we shoot?
answer: Brother, I don't know. If I did I'd tell you. But I just don't know *who's* to blame!

question: Thank God. Oh thank God. Tommy, you didn't *bust* out, didya? You ain't got to hide, have you?
answer: No, Ma. I'm paroled. I got my papers.

question: I was so scared we was goin' away without you--and we'd never see each other again.
answer: I'd a found you, Ma. Muley tol' me what happened, Ma. Are we goin' to California true?

question: We *got* to, Tommy. But that's gonna be awright. I seen the han'bills, about how much work they is, an' high wages, too. But I gotta fin' out somepin' else first, Tommy. Did they hurt you, son? Did they hurt you an' make you mean-mad?
answer: Mad, Ma?

question: Sometimes they do.
answer: No, Ma I was at first--but not no more.

question: Sometimes they do somethin' to you, Tommy. They hurt you--and you get mad--and then you get mean--and they hurt you again--and you get meaner, and meaner--till you ain't no boy or no man any more, but just a walkin' chunk a mean-mad. Did they hurt you like that, Tommy?
answer: No, Ma. You don't have to worry about that.

question: You know what I al'ays said
answer: I didn't bust out. They lemme out. Howya, Noah. Howya, Uncle John.

question: I was the same way myself. Put me in jail and I'd bust right out. Couldn't hold me!
answer: Parole. Rosasharn! Hi, Rosasharn! Howya, Al!

question: Where's Grampa? Al, go git him.
answer: I'm gonna sit up front! Somebody he'p me!

question: You kids climb up first, on top. Al's gonna drive, Ma. You sit up there with him and Granma and we'll swap around later.
answer: I ain't gonna sit with Grampa!

question: Connie, you he'p Rosasharn up there alongside Ruthie and Winfiel'. Where's Grampa?
answer: Where he al'ays is, prob'ly!

question: Ain't nothin' the matter. I just ain't a-goin', that's all.
answer: What you mean you ain't goin'? We *got* to go. We got no place to stay.

question: I ain't talkin' about you, I'm talkin' about me. And I'm a-stayin'. I give her a good goin' over all night long-- and I'm a-stayin'.
answer: But you can't *do* that, Grampa. This here land is goin' under the tractor. We *all* got to git out.

question: Ain't no whisky, is they?
answer: Wait. There's a half a bottle a soothin' sirup here. It put the chillun to sleep.

question: Don't taste bad.
answer: And they's some coffee here. I could fix him a cup...

question: Put somepin' over him, so he won't git sun-struck. Ever'body set now? Awright, Al, letta go! You be awright, Grampa.
answer: Good-by, an' good luck.

question: Hey, wait! Hold 'er, Al! Ain't you goin' with us?
answer: I'd like to. There's somethin' happenin' out there in the wes' an' I'd like to try to learn what it is. If you feel you got the room...

question: Tommy. Wasn't that the state line we just passed?
answer: Yes'm, that was it.

question: Your pa tol' me you didn't ought to cross it if you're paroled. Says they'll send you up again.
answer: Forget it, Ma. I got her figgered out. Long as I keep outa trouble, ain't nobody gonna say a thing. All I gotta do is keep my nose clean.

question: Maybe they got crimes in California we don't know about. Crimes we don't even know *is* crimes.
answer: Forget it, Ma. Jus' think about the nice things out there. Think about them grapes and oranges--an' ever'body got work--

question: Forget it, Ma. Jus' think about the nice things out there. Think about them grapes and oranges--an' ever'body got work--
answer: I gotta git out!

question: First gas station, Granma--
answer: I gotta git *out*, I tell ya! I gotta git *out*!

question: Ma... all this, will it hurt the baby?
answer: Now don't you go gettin' nimsy-mimsy.

question: Sometimes I'm all jumpy inside.
answer: Well, can't nobody get through nine *months* without sorrow.

question: But will it--hurt the baby?
answer: They use' to be a sayin'

question: You don't ever get scairt, do you, Ma?
answer: Sometimes. A little. Only it ain't scairt so much. It's just waitin' an' wonderin'. But when sump'n happens that I got to do sump'n-- --I'll do it.

question: Don't it ever scare you it won't be nice in California like we think?
answer: No. No, it don't. I can't do that. I can't let m'self. All I can do is see how soon they gonna wanta eat again. They'd all get upset if I done anymore 'n that. They all depen' on me jus' thinkin' about that. That's my part--that an' keepin' the fambly together.

question: Wal, y'cain't tell. I figure when we git out there an' git work an' maybe git us a piece a growin' lan' near water it might not be so bad at that.
answer: You folks must have a pot a money.

question: No, we ain't got no money. But they's plenty of us to work, an' we 're all good men. Get good wages out there an' put it all together an' we'll be awright.
answer: Good wages, eh! Pickin' oranges an' peaches?

question: What's so funny about it? I just *been* out there! I been an' *seen* it! An' I'm goin' *back* to starve-- because I ruther starve all over at once!
answer: Whatta you think you're talkin' about? I got a han'bill here says good wages, an' I seen it in the papers they need pickers!

question: Awright, go on! Ain't nobody stoppin' ya!
answer: But what about this?

question: Kinda pie y'got?
answer: Banana cream, pineapple cream, chocolate cream--and apple.

question: Cut me off a hunk a that banana cream, and a cuppa java.
answer: Two it is. Seen any new etchin's lately, Bill?

question: Well, here's one ain't bad. Little kid comes in late to school. Teacher says--
answer: Yeah?

question: Yeah?
answer: Could you see your way clear to sell us a loaf of bread, ma'am.

question: This ain't a groc'ry store. We got bread to make san'widges with.
answer: I know, ma'am... on'y it's for a ole lady, no teeth, gotta sof'n it with water so she can chew it, an' she's hongry.

question: Whyn't you buy a san'wich? We got nice san'widges.
answer: I shore would like to do that, ma'am, but the fack is, we ain't got but a dime for it. It's all figgered out, I mean--for the trip.

question: You can't get no loaf a bread for a dime. We only got fifteen-cent loafs.
answer: Give 'em the bread.

question: We'll run out 'fore the bread truck comes.
answer: Awright then, run out!

question: No, sir, we wanta buy ten cents worth, thas all.
answer: You can have this for ten cents.

question: I don't wanta rob you, ma'am.
answer: Go ahead--Bert says take it.

question: May soun' funny to be so tight, but we got a thousan' miles to go, an' we don't know if we'll make it. Is them penny candy, ma'am?
answer: Which ones?

question: There, them stripy ones.
answer: Oh, them? Well, no--them's *two* for a penny.

question: Where you going?
answer: California.

question: How long you plan to be in Arizona?
answer: No longer'n we can get acrost her.

question: Got any plants?
answer: No plants.

question: Okay. Go ahead, but you better keep movin'.
answer: Sure. We aim to.

question: Never seen such tough mountains. This here's a murder country, just the *bones* of a country. Wonder if we'll ever get in a place where folks can live 'thout fightin' hard scrabble an' rock. Sometimes you get to thinkin' they *ain't* no such country.
answer: How's the swimmin'?

question: Dunno. We ain't tried none. Sure feels good to set here, though.
answer: Mind if we come in an' set?

question: Uncle John don't talk much but when he does he shore talks sense.
answer: You people got a lotta nerve.

question: What you mean?
answer: Crossin' the desert in a jalopy like this.

question: You been acrost?
answer: Sure, plenty, but not in no wreck like this.

question: If we broke down maybe somebody'd give us a han'.
answer: Well, maybe. But I'd hate to be doin' it. Takes more nerve than I got.

question: This here's the desert an' we're right in it!
answer: I wisht it was day.

question: Tom says if it's day it'll cut you gizzard smack out a you. I seen a pitcher once. They was bones ever'place.
answer: Man bones?

question: Well, we got to look over your stuff. You got to unload.
answer: Look, mister. We got a sick ol' lady. We got to get her to a doctor. We can't wait. You can't make us wait!

question: Yeah? Well, we got to look you over.
answer: I swear we ain't got anything. I swear it. An' Granma's awful sick. Look!

question: You wasn't foolin'! You swear you got no fruit or vegetables?
answer: No, I swear it.

question: Where's Ma? I want Ma to see it. Look, Ma! Come here, Ma! Ma, you sick?
answer: Ya say we're acrost?

question: Look, Ma!
answer: Thank God! An' we're still together-- most of us.

question: Didn' you get no sleep?
answer: No.

question: Was Granma bad?
answer: Granma's dead.

question: When?
answer: Since before they stopped us las' night.

question: An' that's why you didn't want 'em to look?
answer: I was afraid they'd stop us an' wouldn't let us cross. But I tol' Granma. I tol' her when she was dyin'. I tol' her the fambly had ta get acrost. I tol' her we couldn't take no chances on bein' stopped. So it's all right. At leas' she'll get buried in a nice green place. Trees and flowers aroun'. She got to lay her head down in California after all.

question: On a gallon a gas? Let's set up the tent. Maybe I can fix us up some stew.
answer: I could break up some bresh if you want me, ma'am.

question: You want to get ast to eat, hunh?
answer: Yes, ma'am.

question: Didn' you have no breakfast?
answer: No, ma'am. They ain't no work hereabouts. Pa's in tryin' to sell some stuff to get gas so's we can get along.

question: Didn' none of these have no breakfast? Then you ain't hungry, are you? Well, it's a good thing *some* a you ain't hungry, because they ain't enough to go all the way roun'.
answer: Aw, he was braggin'. Know what he done? Las' night, come out an' say they got chicken to eat. Well, sir, I looked in whilst they was a-eatin' an' it was fried dough jus' like ever'body else.

question: You take this. I ain't hungry.
answer: Whatta ya mean? You ain't et today.

question: I know, but I got a stomickache. I ain't hungry.
answer: You take that plate inside the tent an' you eat it.

question: Wouldn't be no use. I'd still see 'em inside the tent.
answer: You git. Go on now, git. You ain't doin' no good. They ain't enough for you.

question: Well, I'm contracting the land.
answer: Whay you payin?

question: Well, can't tell exactly, yet. 'Bout thirty cents, I guess.
answer: Why can't you tell? You took the contrac', didn' you?

question: That's true. But it's keyed to the price. Might be a little more, might be a little less.
answer: All right, mister. I'll go. You just show your license to contrack, an' then you make out a order--where an' when an' how much you gonna pay--an' you sign it an' we'll go.

question: You trying to tell me how to run my own business?
answer: 'F we're workin' for you, it's our business too. An' how do we know-- --you ain't one a the guys that sent these things out?

question: Listen, Smart Guy. I'll run my business my own way. I got work. If you wanta take it, okay. If not, just sit here, that's all.
answer: Twicet now I've fell for that line. Maybe he needs a thousan' men. So he get's five thousan' there, an' he'll pay fifteen cents a hour. An' you guys'll have to take it 'cause you'll be hungry. 'F he wants to hire men, let him write it out an' say what he's gonna pay. Ast to see his license. He ain't allowed by law to contrack men without a license.

question: Joe!
answer: You see? If this guy was on the level, would he bring a cop along?

question: What's the trouble?
answer: Ever see this guy before?

question: What'd he do?
answer: He's agitatin'.

question: Gimme that gun. Now git outa here. Go down in them willows an' wait.
answer: I ain't gonna run.

question: He seen you, Tom! You wanta be fingerprinted? You wanta get sent back for breakin' parole?
answer: You're right!

question: Hide in the willows. If it's awright to come back I'll give you four high whistles. Go on. Get in your tent. You don't know nothin'.
answer: How 'bout you?

question: *Some*body got to take the blame. They just *got* to hang it on somebody, you know. An' I ain't doin' nothin' but set around.
answer: But ain't no reason--

question: Lissen. I don't care nothin' about you, but if you mess in this, your whole fambly li'ble to get in trouble, an' Tom get sent back to the penitentiary.
answer: Okay. I think you're a darn fool, though.

question: Sure. Why not?
answer: What's goin' on here?

question: This man a yours, he got tough an' I hit him. Then he started shootin'-- hit a woman down the line--so I hit him again.
answer: Well--what'd you do in the first place?

question: I talked back. They's a woman down there like to bleed to death from his bad shootin'.
answer: Take a look at her. Mike, is this the fella that hit you?

question: You don't know *no* girls around here. You're lyin', *You're runnin' away*!
answer: Cut it out, Ma, or I'll--

question: You'll *what*?... Come on, Pa. Come on an' whup me. Jus' try it.
answer: Now don't get sassy, Ma.

question: Al ain't a-goin' away, an' you gonna *tell* him he ain't a-goin' away. An' if you think diff'unt, you gotta whup me first. So some on.
answer: I never *seen* her so sassy. An' she ain't so young, neither!

question: Maybe that's jus' what he done.
answer: Ma, they comes a time when a man gets mad.

question: Tom--you tol' me--you promised you wasn't like that. You promised me.
answer: I know, Ma. I'm a tryin'. If it was the law they was workin' with, we could take it. But it *ain't* the law. They're workin' away at our spirits. They're tryin' to make us cringe an' crawl. They're workin' on our decency.

question: You promised, Tommy.
answer: I'm a-tryin', Ma. Honest I am.

question: You gotta keep clear, Tom. The fambly's breakin' up. You *got* to keep clear.
answer: What's that--detour?

question: What's that--detour?
answer: Where you think you're goin'?

question: Well-- --we're strangers here. We heard about they's work in a place called Tulare.
answer: Well, you're goin' the wrong way, an' what's more, we don't want no more Okies in this town. We ain't got work enough for them that are already here.

question: Which way is it at, mister?
answer: You turn right aroun' and head north. An' don't come back till the cotton's ready.

question: Where you think you're going?
answer: Fella named Spencer sent us--said they was work pickin' peaches.

question: Want to work, do you?
answer: Sure do.

question: Pull up behind that car. Okay for this one. Take 'em through.
answer: What's the matter? What's happened?

question: I don't know what these cops got to do with it but I don't like it. An' these here are our own people, all of 'em. I don't like this.
answer: Want to work?

question: Sure, but what is this?
answer: That's not your affair. Name.

question: Joad.
answer: How many men?

question: Four.
answer: Women?

question: Two.
answer: Kids?

question: Two.
answer: Can all of you work?

question: Why, I guess so.
answer: Okay. House 63. Wages 5 cents a box. No bruised fruit. Move along and go to work right away.

question: This got a floor. Wouldn't leak when it rains.
answer: It's still Joad.

question: Six. All y'all go. Me an' Rosasharn'll unload.
answer: Got any more, Ma?

question: Okay, Ma. Don't you worry.
answer: Where you think you're going?

question: Thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?
answer: Well, you just turn around and walk the other way.

question: You mean I can't even get outa here?
answer: Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?

question: I'll walk back. Evenin'.
answer: Who are you?

question: Jus' goin' pas', that's all.
answer: Know anybody here?

question: No. Jus' goin' pas', I tell you.
answer: What's the matter?

question: Casy! What you doin' here?
answer: Well, if it ain't Tom Joad. How ya, boy?

question: Thought you was in jail.
answer: No, I done my time an' got out. Come on in.

question: Workin'. Pickin' peaches. But I seen a bunch a fellas yellin' when we come in, so I come out to see what's goin' on. What's it all about?
answer: This here's a strike.

question: Well, fi' cents a box ain't much, but a fella can eat.
answer: Fi' cents! They pain' you fi' cents?

question: Sure. We made a buck since midday.
answer: Lookie, Tom. We come to work here. They tell us it's gonna be fi' cents. But they was a whole lot of us, so the man says two an' a half cents. Well, a fella can't even eat on that, an' if he got kids... So we says we won't take it. So they druv us off. Now they're payin' you five--but when they bust this strike ya think they'll pay five?

question: I dunno. Payin' five now.
answer: I don't expeck we can las' much longer-- some a the folks ain't et for two days. You goin' back tonight?

question: I aim to.
answer: Well--tell the folks inside how it is, Tom. Tell 'em they're starvin' us and stabbin' theirself in the back. An' as sure as God made little apples it's goin' back to two an' a half jus' as soon as they clear us out.

question: 'Tain't outa the question, y'know.
answer: All of us a little itchy. Cops been tellin' us how they gonna beat us up an' run us outa the country. Not them reg'lar deppities, but them tin- star fellas they got for guards. They figger I'm the leader because I talk so much.

question: Turn out that light an' come outside. They's sump'n here.
answer: What is it?

question: I dunno. Listen.
answer: Can't tell if you hear it or not. You hear it, Tom?

question: Stand by the door. How's it feel, Tommy?
answer: Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?

question: Looks like you done it.
answer: I kinda thought so. Felt like it.

question: Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.
answer: They killed Casy first.

question: That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.
answer: They know what--this fella looks like?

question: They know he got hit in the face.
answer: I'm sorry, Ma. But--I didn't know what I was doin', no more'n when you take a breath. I didn't even know I was gonna do it.

question: It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.
answer: I'm gonna go away tonight. I can't go puttin' this on you folks.

question: Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us. They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Ol' folks died off, an' little fellas come, an' we was always one thing-- we was the fambly--kinda whole an' clear. But now we ain't clear no more. They ain't nothin' keeps us clear. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn-- --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.
answer: Okay, Ma. I shouldn't, though. I know I shouldn't. But okay.

question: Yeah? Let's have a look at you. Wasn't there another fella with you?
answer: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?

question: I guess that's what he looked like.
answer: We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.

question: What'd he look like again?
answer: Short fella. Pale face.

question: Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?
answer: I didn't see nothin'.

question: Okay. Go on.
answer: Yeah. Goin' north. Got a job.

question: Full up. Uncle John come through with five bucks he been hol'in' out on us since we lef' home. She's hotter'n a heifer.
answer: Fan-belt's shot.

question: Picks a nice place for it, too, don't she? Any gas?
answer: Gallon or two?

question: You hit 'er too fast.
answer: What's the idea of that?

question: Well, a lot a kids play in here. You tell folks to go slow and they liable to forget. But let 'em hit that hump once and they don't forget!
answer: Got any room here for us?

question: You're lucky. Fellow just moved out half-hour ago. Down that line and turn to the left. You'll see it. You'll be in No. 4 Sanitary Unit.
answer: What's that?

question: Toilet and showers and washtubs.
answer: You mean you got *washtubs?* An' runnin' water?

question: Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.
answer: We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?

question: We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.
answer: Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?

question: That's the way it is.
answer: An' you say no cops?

question: No cop can come in here without a warrant.
answer: I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.

question: They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.
answer: You got dances too?

question: We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.
answer: Say, who runs this place?

question: Government.
answer: Why ain't they more like it?

question: *You* find out, I can't.
answer: Anything like work aroun' here?

question: Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.
answer: Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.

question: That cut you got?
answer: Crate fell on me.

question: Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.
answer: Goodnight. Good mornin'.

question: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!
answer: Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!

question: I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!
answer: Lissen. You done busted it. You hear? But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?

question: Please don't.
answer: I won't-- --if you won't tell what *I* done!

question: Well, look out next Saturday night.
answer: What you mean? I belong to the central committee. I got to know.

question: Don't you ever tell I told.
answer: What is it?

question: Ma... Ma, I--I can't go to the dance. I jus' can't Ma. I can't hardly stan' it, with Connie not here--an' me this way.
answer: Why, honey, it makes folks happy to see a girl that way--makes folks sort of giggly an' happy.

question: I can't he'p it, Ma. It don't make *me* giggly an' happy.
answer: You an' me's goin' together--jus' you an' me. We're a-goin' to that dance an' we're a-goin' to jus' set an' watch. If anybody says to come dance--why I'll say you're poorly. But you an' me, we're gonna hear the music an' see the fun.

question: An' you won't let nobody touch me?
answer: No--an' look what I got for you. I used to wear these--when your pa come callin' on me. You'll look pretty in 'em tonight.

question: Open up! We hear you got a riot.
answer: Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?

question: Deputy sheriffs.
answer: Got a warrant?

question: We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.
answer: Well, I don't know what you gonna do about it, because I don't hear no riot an' I don't see no riot, an' what's more I don't believe they *is* no riot. Look for yourself. You got no right to arrest anybody without a warrant, you know.

question: Ain't you gonna tell me goodbye, Tommy?
answer: I didn't know, Ma. I didn't know if I ought. Come outside. They was some cops here, Ma. They was takin' down the license numbers. It looks like somebody knows sump'n.

question: It had to come, I reckon, soon or later.
answer: I'd like to stay. I'd like to be with ya-- --an' see your face when you an' Pa get settled in a nice little place. I sure wish I could see you then. But-- --I guess I won't never be able to do that. Not now.

question: I could hide you, Tommy.
answer: I know you would, Ma. But I ain't gonna let you. You hide somebody that's kilt a man an'... an' you'd be in trouble too.

question: Awright, Tommy. What you figger you gonna do?
answer: You know what I been thinkin' about, Ma? About Casy. About what he said, what he done, an' about how he died. An' I remember all of it.

question: He was a good man.
answer: I been thinkin' about us, too--about our people livin' like pigs, an' good rich lan' layin' fallow, or maybe one fella with a million acres, while a hundred thousan' farmers is starvin'. An' I been wonderin' if all our folks got together an' yelled--

question: Tommy, they'll drive you, an' cut you down like they done to Casy.
answer: They gonna drive me anyways. Soon or later they'll get me, for one thing if not another. Until then...

question: You don't aim to kill nobody, Tom!
answer: No, Ma. Not that. That ain't it. But long as I'm a outlaw, anyways, maybe I can do sump'n. Maybe I can jus' fin' out sump'n. Jus' scrounge aroun' an' try to fin' out what it is that's wrong, an then see if they ain't sump'n could be done about it. But I ain't thought it out clear, Ma. I can't. I don't know enough.

question: How'm I gonna know 'bout you? They might kill you an' I wouldn't know. They might hurt you. How'm I gonna know?
answer: Well, maybe it's like Casy says, a fella ain't got a soul of his own, but on'y a piece of a big soul--the one big soul that belongs to ever'body-- an' then...

question: Then what, Tom?
answer: Then it don't matter. Then I'll be all aroun' in the dark. I'll be ever'where--wherever you look. Wherever there's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever there's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad--an' I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry an' they know supper's ready. An' when our people eat the stuff they raise, an' live in the houses they build, why, I'll be there too.

question: I don't understan' it, Tom.
answer: Me neither. It's jus' stuff I been thinkin' about. Gimme you han', Ma. Good-by.

question: Good-by, Tom. Later--when it's blowed over--you'll come back? You'll try to fin' us?
answer: Sure. Good-by.

question: I'll get Rosasharn.
answer: All aboard, ever'body! All aboard for Fresno!

question: Try to be strong, honey. Someday it'll be diff'rent--someday you'll have another one. You're still jus' a little girl, remember.
answer: Make her easy, John. Watch her.
